unnormalised: I was so confused when I first started working with my company's international team. We have folks in Delhi, London and NYC. Trying to schedule meetings was a NIGHTMARE. I’d put something on my calendar for, say, 2:00 PM, and then get a reminder at what felt like completely random times. Like, who schedules a meeting for 2:30 AM?!
normalised: I was so confused when I first started working with my company's international team. We have folks in Delhi, London and N-Y-C. Trying to schedule meetings was a nightmare. I’d put something on my calendar for, say, two P-M, and then get a reminder at what felt like completely random times. Like, who schedules a meeting for two thirty A-M?!

unnormalised: The first time it happened, I actually missed a crucial client presentation. I had scheduled it for 2 PM my time (IST), thinking that was a reasonable time for everyone. Turns out, 2 PM in India is like, 9:30 AM in London (GMT+1) and 4:30 AM in NYC (EST). My colleague, Aisha, gently explained to me that I need to use a time zone converter or something! She suggested I use UTC as the base, since everyone knows that. Lesson learned the hard way.
normalised: The first time it happened, I actually missed a crucial client presentation. I had scheduled it for two P-M my time (I-S-T), thinking that was a reasonable time for everyone. Turns out, two P-M in India is like, nine thirty A-M in London (G-M-T plus one) and four thirty A-M in N-Y-C (E-S-T). My colleague, Aisha, gently explained to me that I need to use a time zone converter or something! She suggested I use U-T-C as the base, since everyone knows that. Lesson learned the hard way.

unnormalised: Now, I always double-check the time zones. I prepone meetings that I know are hard for other teams and rotate the timings. I’ve even gotten pretty good at doing the mental math. For instance, if it's 10:00 AM IST, I know it's probably 5:30 AM in London. I also ask everyone to always include their timezone in any meeting invites. It’s saved me from a lot more 2:30 AM wake-up calls.

For instance, if it's ten A-M I-S-T, I know it's probably five thirty A-M in London. I also ask everyone to always include their timezone in any meeting invites. It’s saved me from a lot more two thirty A-M wake-up calls.
